questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of Fatty Acid Synthase Complex?
questions.solution:
Fatty Acid Synthase (FAS) Multienzyme Complex

  • ACP contains the vitamin Pantothenic acid in the form of 4’-phosphopantetheine
  • X-ray crystallography of the three-dimensional structure, shown that the complex is arranged in an X shape
  • Acetyl CoA carboxylase is not a part FAS Complex

Binds to a receptor and cholesterol diffuses across the cell membrane.
On accumulation in the cell inhibits replenish ment of LDL receptors.

questions.text: Cholesterol present in LDL:
questions.solution:
• Option A: LDL cholesterol is primarily from other lipoproteins where as HDL cholesterol is from peripheral organs.
  • Option B: Mechanism of uptake of LDL by LDL receptor
    • LDL receptors occur on the cell surface in pits that are coated on the cytosolic side of the cell membrane with a protein called clathrin.
    • The LDL receptor spans the membrane, the B-100 binding region being at the exposed amino terminal end.
    • After binding, LDL is taken up intact by
    • The apoprotein and cholesteryl ester are then hydrolyzed in the lysosomes, and cholesterol is translocated into the cell.
    • The receptors are recycled to the cell surface.
  • Option C: LDL is taken up intact, and not cholesterol alone diffuses across the Cholesterol balance in tissues

This influx of cholesterol inhibits the transcription of the genes encoding

  • HMG-CoA synthase, HMG-CoA reductase, and other enzymes involved in cholesterol synthesis
  • The LDL receptor itself, via the SREBP pathway

Thus coordinately suppresses cholesterol synthesis and uptake.

  • Option D:In addition, ACAT activity is stimulated, promoting cholesterol

Reference: Harper 30/e p271

Lp(a)

  • Almost similar to LDL.
  • Apo (a) is attached to apo B100 by disulphide
  • Major site of clearance of Lp(a) is
  • Strongly associated with Atherosclerosis and Myocardial infarction.
  • Significant homology with PlasminogenQ.

  • Hence fibrin clot is no lysed.

questions.text: A children present with seizure at emergency room. On examination dr found tone of muscle is reduced. On investigation patient is diagnosed with Zellweger Syndrome. So which of the following is accumulated in brain?
questions.solution:
Zellweger syndrome is a rare congenital disorder characterized by the reduction or absence of functional peroxisomes in the cells of an individual.

It is one of a family of disorders called Zellweger spectrum disorders which are leukodystrophies

Zellweger syndrome is associated with impaired neuronal migration, neuronal positioning, and brain development.

In addition, individuals with Zellweger syndrome can show a reduction in central nervous system (CNS) myelin (particularly cerebral), which is referred to as hypomyelination

As a result of impaired peroxisome function, an individual's tissues and cells can accumulate very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA) and branched chain fatty acids (BCFA) that are normally degraded in peroxisomes. The accumulation of these lipids can impair the normal function of multiple organ systems.

Reference: Harper 31st e 532

choices.text: Bond is formed between carboxy terminal of one protein and amino group of a lysine residue on another
Involves in post-transcriptional modification of protein
Enzyme act as catalyst for bond formation

questions.text: Which of the following sentence is false about pseudopeptide:
questions.solution:
Pseudopeptide Bond is also called as Atypical Peptide Bond

A bond formed between an amino group and a carboxyl group at least one of which is not an alpha group. Seen in the side chains of proteins.

Characteristic Features

  • Occur post-translationally
  • Can be formed spontaneously or enzymatically
  • Can produce stably linked protein dimers, multimers or complexes
  • Makes the protein resistant as proteases cannot hydrolyse isopeptide bond.

Examples

  • Glutathione
  • Thyrotropin Releasing Hormone
  • Ubiquitin attached to protein
  • Blood clots.

Sometime it is known as Isopeptide Bond

Ref: MN chatterjea and rana shindepage 8e page 88

Application of spontaneous Isopeptide Bond formation

  • Develop a new peptide tag called Used in:
  • In vivo Protein targeting
  • Fluorescence Microscopy Imaging.

questions.text: Ammonia level in blood increase in?
questions.solution:
Increased ammonia in blood is suggestive of a urea cycle disorder. So answer is an enzyme (deficiency) of urea cycle.

There are different types of Urea Cycle disorders.

Hyperammonemia Type II (OTC Deficiency)
  • Most common Urea Cycle disorder
  • Disorder with X-linked partially dominant inheritance (All other Urea Cycle Disorders are Autosomal Recessive)
  • Levels of glutamine are elevated in blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and urine, probably as a result of enhanced glutamine synthesis in response to elevated levels of tissue ammonia.

Reference : Harper 31st e , page 683

questions.text: In a mutation if valine is replaced by which of the following would not result in any change in the function of protein:
questions.solution:
Homologous substitution or Conservative mutation won’t result in any change in function of the proteins examples for homologous substitution

Hydrophilic, Acidic = Asp, Glu

Hydrophilic, Basic= His,Arg,Lys

Polar, Uncharged = Ser,Thr.Gln,Asn

Hydrophobic =Ala,Phe,Leu,Ile,Val,Pro

Homologs, Orthologs and Paralogs

When two genes share detectable sequence similarities (nucleotide sequence in DNA and amino acid sequence in the proteins they encode), their sequence are said to be homologous and the proteins encoded by them are called homologs.

Homologs arises from a common ancestor.

Homologs can be orthologs orparalogs.

  • Homologous genes in same species, are said to be paralogous and their protein products are Paralogous genes are result of gene duplication.
    • Paralogs are similar not only in sequence of amino acids but also in the three dimensional
  • Homologous genes in different species, are said to be orthologous and their protein products are
    • The sequence difference between homologous gene may be taken as a rough measure of degree to which two species have diverged during

Ref: Vasudevan 7e page 24,25

questions.text: Which of the following act as Suicidal Enzymes:
questions.solution:
Cyclooxygenase is a 'Suicide Enzyme' 'Switching off' of prostaglandin activity is partly achieved by a remarkable property of cyclooxygenase - that of self-catalysed destruction; i.e. it is a 'suicide enzyme'.

Cyclooxygenase

  • Cyclooxygenase (COX) (also called prostaglandin H synthase)
  • Involved in prostanoid (prostaglandin. Thromboxane and Prostacyclin) synthesis
  • This enzyme has two activities, a cyclooxygenase and peroxidase
  • COX is present as two isoenzymes, COX-1 and COX-2.

Drugs acting as inhibitors COX

  • NSAID
    • Aspirin: Inhibits COX-1 and COX-2.
    • Indomethacin and ibuprofen-inhibit cyclooxygenase by competing with
    • Coxibs: Selectively inhibit COX-2
    • Some coxibs have been withdrawn or suspended from the market due to undesirable side effects and safety issues.
  • Anti-inflammatory Corticosteroids
    • Transcription of COX-2—but not of COX-1—is completely inhibited by

Reference: Harper 30/e p241

questions.solution:
• Special group in phenylalanine is benzene ring
  • Special group in Tyrosine is Phenol ring
  • The enzyme that hydroxylate Phenylalanine to Tyrosine is Phenylalanine Hydroxylase

questions.text: Estimation of Plasma Glucose can be done by all methods except
questions.solution:
Ferric Chloride test is the test done in Amino Acid Metabolism Disorders like Alkaptonuria and Phenyl Ketonuria.

Methods for estimation of glucose

  • Nelson-Somogyi Method
  • Folin-Wu Method
  • O-Toluidine Method

Enzymatic method

Hexokinase Method

Glucose Oxidase-Peroxidase Method (GOD –POD)

Glucose Dehydrogenase Method

  • Highly Specific Method
  • Used in dry analysis technique like

Reaction

Principle of Glucose Oxidase Peroxidase

Glucose + H2O +O2 –--------GOD--------> Gluconic Acid + H2O2

4 Amino Phenazone +Phenol +H2O2 --------POD------> Quinonimine –Pink Colour compound.

Reference; Vasudevan 7e Page 313

questions.text: All of the following enzymes are involved in oxidation-reduction, except:
questions.solution:
Following enzymes act as an Oxidoreductases :

  • Dehydrogenase
  • Oxygenase
  • Monooxygenase
  • Dioxygenase
  • Oxidase
  • Catalase
  • Peroxidase

Dehydrogenase

Catalyze removal of hydrogen from the substrate.

They cannot use oxygen as a hydrogen acceptor.

Oxidases

Removal of hydrogen from a substrate with oxygen as the acceptor of hydrogen.

  • Monoamine Oxidase
  • Cytochrome Oxidase
  • Xanthine Oxidase

Oxygenases

Catalyze the direct transfer and incorporation of oxygen into a substrate molecule.

Monooxygenases [Mixed Function Oxidases or Hydroxylase]

Incorporate one atom of molecular oxygen into the substrate:

  • Phenylalanine Hydroxylases
  • 7 alpha Hydroxylases
  • Cytochrome

Dioxygenases

Incorporate both atoms of molecular oxygen into the substrate. The basic reaction is shown below:

A + O → AO

Examples of Dioxygenase

  • Homogentisate oxidase
  • Tryptophan Pyrrolase (Dioxygenase)
  • Nitric Oxide

Reference : Harper 30/e p118, 119

questions.text: Amino acid will increase UV absorbance of protein at 280 nm wavelength:
questions.solution:
Amino Acid Absorb UV Light

Amino Acids which absorb 250–290 nm (Maximum at 280 nm) UV light are tryptophan, phenylalanine, tyrosine. Maximum absorption of UV light by tryptophan.

Aromatic amino acids absorb UV light

Reference:- Harper 30/e p21, 22

questions.text: Which of the following are enantiomers:
questions.solution:
Difference in the orientation of H and OH group around Penultimate Carbon atom results in two mirror images called D and L isomers (Enantiomers).

The penultimate carbon atom is called Reference Carbon atom. The penultimate carbon atom in Glucose and Fructose is C-5.

Most of the naturally occurring Monosaccharides are D isomers [Unlike Amino Acids, which are L isomers.]

Examples of Enantiomers

D Glucose and L Glucose

D Fructose and L Fructose

D Mannose and L Mannose

D Glyceraldehyde and L Glyceraldehyde.

Ref: Harper 31/e p 367

questions.text: Which is true about enzyme kinetics for competitive inhibition:
questions.solution:
Significance of Km (Michaelis Constant):

  • Km is substrate concentration at 1/2 Vmax
  • It is called signature of the enzyme
  • Higher the Km, lower is the affinity of the enzyme towards the substrate
  • Lower the Km, higher is the affinity of the enzyme towards the substrate.

Features of competitive inhibition:

  • Km increases, hence the affinity is lowered
  • Vmax remains the

Features of noncompetitive inhibition:

  • Km remains the same
  • Vmax

Reference:- Harper 30/e p78

  • Amino acid whose pKa = pH of the medium has maximum buffering
  • At pH = 7, Imidazole group of histidine can act as

questions.text: Carbonyl terminal of which amino acid cleaves by Chymotrypsin :
questions.solution:
Serine Proteases

  • Proteolytic Enzymes with Serine at their active Site
  • Amino acid triad in the active site of Serine Proteases: Ser, His,

Examples of serine proteases

  • Chymotrypsin
  • Trypsin
  • Elastase
  • Thrombin
  • Plasmin
  • Complements
  • Factor X and

Serine proteases differ in substrate specificity

  • Trypsin cleave Basic Amino Acid, like Arg, Lys
  • Chymotrypsin cleave Hydrophobic Bulky Amino Acid like Trp, Tyr, Phe
  • Elastase cleave Small neutral AminoAcids like Alanine, Glycine

Reference: Harper 30/e p64

questions.text: Amino acid transported by
questions.solution:
Free amino acids are absorbed across the intestinal mucosa by sodium-dependent active transport.

There are several different amino acid transporters, with specificity for the nature of the amino acid side-chain.

Transporters of Amino Acids

  • For Neutral Amino Acids
  • For Basic Amino acids and Cysteine
  • For Imino Acids and Glycine
  • For Acidic Amino Acids
  • For Beta Amino Acids (Beta Alanine)

Meisters Cycle

  • For absorption of Neutral Amino acids from Intestines, Kidney tubules and brain.
  • The main role is played by Glutathione. (GSH)
  • For transport of 1 amino acid and regeneration of GSH 3 ATPs are

Disorders associated with Meister’s Cycle is Oxoprolinuria

  • 5 Oxoprolinase deficiency leads to Oxoprolinuria

Reference : Harper 30/e p539

questions.text: Glycogenin is a:
questions.solution:
• Glycogenin is a protein
  • 37 K Da protein
  • Glycogenin catalyzes transfer of 7 glucosyl residues from UDPGlucose, in alpha 1 → 4 linkage
  • Glucosyl residues are added on specific tyrosine residues of Glycogenin
  • Glycogenin remains at the core of Glycogen

Reference: Harper 30/e p177

questions.text: A 1 year old baby not taking feed for few days and presented with skin lesions, seizures, ketosis, organic acids in urine with normal ammonia; likely diagnosis:
questions.solution: Reference: Harper 31ePage 560, 682, 721

questions.text: A breast feed infant come with frequent vomiting and lose of weight. After many days he have develop jaundice, hepatomegaly, bilateral cataract. What is the possible diagnosis of this child?
questions.solution:
Bilateral cataract is characteristics of Galactosemia.

Clinical manifestation of liver affected when milk is diet, is typical of galactosemia.

Bilateral cataract is not characteristics of HFI, Von Gierke’s disease,Gaucher disease.

Juvenile DM no hepatomegaly and jaundice is seen.

Reference: Harper 30e Page 205

questions.text: Which of these is a conservative mutation:
questions.solution:
Definition of Conservative Mutation:- Conservative mutation means an amino acid replaced by another amino acid of same characteristics.

Glutamic acid: Negatively Charged Polar = Glutamine: Uncharged Polar

Histidine: Positively Charged Polar= Glycine: Uncharged Nonpolar

Alanine-Uncharged Nonpolar= Leucine: Uncharged Nonpolar

Arginine: Positively Charged Polar= Aspartic Acid: Negatively Charged Polar

Reference: Vasudevan 7th e page26.

choices.text: Oxygen is require for conversion of glucose to lactate
Fructose 2,6 Biphosphate is a inhibitor of PFK.
Enzyme hexokinase is a important in hepatic glucose metabolism only in absorption after meal

questions.text: Glycolysis is a breakdown of glucose. True about glycolysis is?
questions.solution:
Hexokinase, PFK, Pyruvate kinase are irreversible steps and regulated steps in glycolysis.

Conversion of glucose to lactate is anaerobic glycolysis and no oxygen required.

Enzyme glucokinase(not hexokinase) is a important in hepatic glucose metabolism only in absorption after meal.

Reference: Harper 30/e p 171-172

questions.text: Glycogen phosphorylase can be regulated by all the following except:
questions.solution:
Regulation of Glycogen metabolism at Glycogen Phosphorylase

  • cAMP activates Glycogen Phosphorylase by cAMP- dependent Protein Kinase
  • cAMP-independent Calcium/Calmodulin-sensitive Kinase also activates Glycogen Phosphorylase.

Glycogenin is a protein on which initial glucose is added in the synthesis of Glycogen.

Phosphorylase kinase is activated in response to cAMP.

Increasing the concentration of cAMP activates cAMP-dependent protein kinase, which catalyzes the phosphorylation by ATP of inactive phosphorylase kinase b to active phosphorylase kinase a, which in turn, phosphorylates phosphorylase b to phosphorylase a.

In the liver, cAMP is formed in response to glucagon, which is secreted in response to falling blood glucose.

Muscle is insensitive to glucagon; in muscle, the signal for increased cAMP formation is the action of norepinephrine, which is secreted in response to fear or fright, when there is a need for increased glycogenolysis to permit rapid muscle activity.

Calmodulin calcium binding protein and binds four Ca2+. The binding of Ca2+ activates the catalytic site of the γ subunit even while the enzyme is in the dephosphorylated b state; the phosphorylated a form is only fully activated in the presence of high concentrations of Ca2+.

Reference : Harper 31/e p423,424-182

questions.text: A novel DNA editing system termed CRISPR-Cas9 (clustered regularly interspersed short palindromic repeats - associated gene 9) has revolutionized genomic DNA studies. Which of the following is true for CRISPR-Cas9?
questions.solution:
Option B: CRISPR-Cas9 system is directed by guide RNA and cleave specific site in between long chain of DNA, so it is RNA directed site specific endonuclease system.

The endonuclease cleaves or cuts the DNA from inside or in between the sequence while the exonuclease cut the DNA on the ends.

Option A: CRISPR-Cas9 system having endonuclease activity but not directed by DNA.

Option C: CRISPR-Cas9 system directed by RNA, but not having exonuclease activity.

Option D: CRISPR-Cas9 system neither directed by DNA nor having exonuclease activity.

CRISPR-Cas9

It is a novel Gene editing or gene regulatory technique

It was recognized by Emmanuelle Charpentier and Jennifer Doudna (awarded Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2020).

CRISPR: clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats

  • CRISPR found in genomes of prokaryotic organism (in bacterial and archaea).

It found in approximately 50% of sequenced bacterial genomes and 90% of sequenced archaea.

  • These sequences are originally derived from DNA fragments of bacteriophages that had previously infected the prokaryote.

Later they are used by prokaryotes to detect and destroy DNA from similar bacteriophages during subsequent infections to prokaryotes.

So these sequences play role as an antiviral (antiphase) defense system for prokaryotes and provide an acquired or adaptive immunity to prevent reinfection of a bacterium by specific bacteriophages

  • CRISPR comple­ments the system of restriction endonucleases and methyl­ases. CRISPR uses RNA-based targeting to bring the Cas9 nuclease to foreign (or any complementary) DNA.

CAS9: CRISPR associated protein 9

  • An endonuclease enzyme
  • It uses CRISPR sequences as a guide (as guide RNA).
  • Then recognizes specific DNA strands that are complementary to CRISPR sequence & cleave them.

CRISPR CAS9

  • Both together are used to edit genes within organisms.
  • Within bacteria this CRISPR-RNA-Cas9 complex then degrades and inactivates the targeted DNA.

The CRISPR system has been also adapted for use in eukaryotic cells, including human cells, where it has been shown to be an RNA-directed site-specific nuclease just as it is in bacteria.

  • It has wide varieties of application in medicine, in basic biological research, food and farming industries.

In medicine, it was used to experimentally to treat a patient with a genetic disorder (eg sickle cell disease), to treat viral infection like HIV etc.

  • Variations on the use of CRISPR allow for gene deletion, gene editing, gene visualization, and even modulation of gene transcription in basic biological research.

Thus, CRISPR has added an exciting new, highly efficient, and very specific technology to the toolbox of methods for the manipulation of DNA and genetic analysis of mamma­lian cells.

  • A variant of the CRISPR-Cas system, C2c2, has been shown to site-specifically cleave RNA. This exciting discovery paves the way for poten­tial specific alteration of mRNA levels in human cells.


Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 435

choices.text: two Fab fragments and two Fc fragments
two Fab fragments and one Fc fragment
three Fab fragments and two Fc fragments
three Fab fragments and three Fc fragments

questions.text: Papain is a proteolytic enzyme extracted from plant of papaya (carica papaya). It catalyses protein breakdown by hydrolysis. It a single Immunoglobulin G (IgG) molecule is treated with this enzyme, then IgG will breakdown into following fragments?
questions.solution:
Proteolytic cleavage of Immunoglobulin:

Immunoglobulin can be split by enzyme papain & Pepsin.

  • Papain cleaves at N-terminal side of inter heavy chain disulphide bonds, so produces two identical Fab and one Fc part.
  • Pepsin cleaves at C-terminal side of inter heavy chain disulphide bonds, so produces a large F(ab)2 fragment (composed of two attached Fab fragments) and Fc fragment is extensively degraded.


Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 641

questions.text: All of the following biochemical mechanisms are responsible for increased uric acid level in patient with Lesch Nyhan Syndrome, except:
questions.solution:
Lesch nyhan syndrome occurs due to Inherited deficiency of HGPRT enzymes.



Option A: The rate of salvage pathway reaction is decreased; it results in increase intracellular PRPP level.

Option B: If HGPRT is absent, hypoxanthine and guanine is increased, as they will not be reutilized, so increased its catabolism lead to increased uric acid level.

Option C: Accumulation of PRPP lead to increase purine nucleotide synthesis, which when breakdown produces uric acid.

Option D: Increase synthesis of ribose can also lead to increase uric acid level in patient of gout which occurs due to glucose 6 phosphatase deficiency. Not in Lesch Nyhan syndrome (HGPRTase deficiency).

LESCH NYHAN SYNDROME

  • Clinical disorder of defective salvage pathway
  • Inherited deficiency of HGPRT enzymes

Inheritance: X linked recessive

  • Normal HGPRT reaction:

Guanine + PRPP →GMP + PPi

Hypoxanthine + PRPP →IMP + PPi

  • Clinical features:
    • Increased uric acid level (Hyperuricemia) and Gout,
    • Nephrolithiasis (Renal stone)
    • Mental retardation
    • Severe neurologic disease, characterized by self-mutilating behaviors such as lip and finger biting and/or head banging
    • Up to 20 times the uric acid in the urine than in normal individuals. Uric acid crystals form in the urine.
    • Untreated condition results in death within the first year due to kidney failure.
  • Treatment: Allopurinol to reduce uric acid level, a competitive inhibitor of xanthine oxidase. CNS symptom doesn’t respond to allopurinol

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 334

choices.text: Synthesis purine nucleotide from amphibolic intermediates

questions.text: Which of the following is considered as nonessential with respect to purine nucleotide pool which are used for synthesis of nucleic acid in most human tissues?
questions.solution:
Purine nucleotide pool are used for synthesis of nucleic acid in human tissues. All tissue gets such nucleotides to meet their physiological demand by

Option A: Denovo synthesis in tissue (Synthesis purine nucleotide from amphibolic intermediates)

Option B: Attachment of ribose 5 phosphate into purine nitrogen bases (Phosphoribosylation of purines)

Purine N base + PRPP -> Purine mono nucleotide + PPi

Option C: Attachment Phosphate into purine nucleoside (Phosphorylation of purine nucleosides)

Purine Nucleoside + ATP -> Purine mono nucleotide + ADP

Option D: Ingested nucleic acids and nucleotides are considered as dietary nones­sential. Following their degradation in the intestinal tract, the resulting mononucleotides may be absorbed or converted to purine and pyrimidine bases. The purine bases are then oxi­dized to uric acid, which may be absorbed and excreted in the urine. While little or no dietary purine or pyrimidine is incorporated into tissue nucleic acids.

But injected nucleotide compounds are seen to be incorporated in nucleic acid synthesis. So the incorporation of injected thymidine into newly synthesized DNA thus can be used to measure the rate of DNA synthesis.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 328

questions.text: All of the following condition can lead to hypouricemia except:
questions.solution:
Uric acid is end product of purine catabolism. It is a waste product and excreted by kidney. Normal uric acid level in blood is 3.5 to 6.5 mg/dl in female & 3.5 to 7 mg/dl in male.

Hyperuricemia is a increased uric acid level in blood. It can lead to gout.

Hypouricemia is a reduced uric acid level in blood.

Option A: Liver is the major site of purine nucleotide biosynthesis, even liver provides purines and purine nucleosides for salvage and for utilization by tissues incapable of their biosynthesis. So liver cirrhosis will reduce purine nucleotide and their catabolism into uric acid is also reduced.

Option B: Uric acid is excreted by kidney, so renal failure will reduce excretion of uric acid, thus increase uric acid level, leading to hyperuricemia.

Option C: Xanthine oxidase enzyme convert Hypoxanthine into Xanthine and Xanthine into Uric acid. So genetic defect in xanthine oxidase will reduce uric acid formation and lead to hypouricemia.

Option D: Allopurinol inhibit xanthine oxidase enzyme, so reduces uric acid formation and reduces uric acid level, may lead to hypouricemia. Allopurinol is commonly used drug in gout.

Note: Deficiency of ADA (adenosine deaminase) enzyme can also lead to hypouricemia.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 335

choices.text: Composed of Heavy (H) and light (L) chains
Genetic code differs slightly from standard code
Low mutation rate compare to nuclear DNA

questions.text: All of the following is true about mitochondrial DNA except:
questions.solution:
Option A: Mitochondrial DNA is circular, double stranded DNA (nuclear DNA is linear and double stranded)

Option B: Composed of two strands which considered as Heavy (H) and light (L) chains

Option C: Genetic code of mitochondrial DNA slightly differs from the standard code

UGA (standard stop codon) is read as Trp (Tryptophan)

AGA and AGG (standard codons for Arg - Arginine) are read as stop codons

Option D: High mutation rate compare to nuclear DNA (5-10 times that of nuclear DNA)

Specific feature of Human mitochondrial DNA

  • Contains 2 to 10 copies of a small circular Double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) molecule
  • Composed of heavy (H) and light (L) chains or strands
  • Contains 16,569 bp (~16 kbp)
  • Makes up approximately 1% of total cellular DNA
  • The majority of the polypeptides in mitochondria (about 54 out of 67) are encoded by nuclear genes, but some are coded by genes found in mitochondrial (mt) DNA.

Encodes 13 protein subunits of the respiratory chain (of a total of about 67)

Seven subunits of NADH dehydrogenase (complex I)

Cytochrome b of complex III

Three subunits of cytochrome oxidase (complex IV)

Two subunits of ATP synthase

  • Encodes large (16S) and small (12S) mt ribosomal RNAs

Encodes 22 mt tRNA molecules

  • Genetic code differs slightly from the standard code

UGA (standard stop codon) is read as Trp

AGA and AGG (standard codons for Arg) are read as stop codons

  • Contains very few untranslated sequences
  • High mutation rate (5-10 times that of nuclear DNA)
  • Comparisons of mtDNA sequences provide evidence about evolutionary origins of primates and other species
  • An important feature of human mitochondrial mtDNA is that it is transmitted by maternal nonmendelian inheritance, because all mitochondria are contributed by the ovum during zygote formation. Thus, in diseases resulting from mutations of mtDNA, an affected mother would theoretically pass the disease to all of her children, but only her daughters would transmit the trait.
  • However, in some cases, deletions in mtDNA occur during oogenesis and thus are not inherited from the mother.
  • A number of diseases have now been shown to be due to mutations of mtDNA. These include a variety of myopathies, neurologic disorders, and some forms of diabetes mellitus.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 359

questions.text: Chromatin consists of all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Chromatin is the chromosomal material in the nuclei of cells of eukaryotic organisms. Chromatin consists of

Option A: very long double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) molecules. The dsDNA helix in each chromo­some has a length that is thousands of times the diameter of the cell nucleus

Option B: small basic proteins termed histones. The histones help to condense the DNA, also inte­grally participate in gene regulation.

Option C: smaller amount of nonhistone proteins (most of which are acidic and larger than histones). The nonhistone pro­teins include enzymes involved in DNA replication and repair, and the proteins involved in RNA synthesis, processing, and transport to the cytoplasm.

Option D: small quantity of RNA

Electron microscopic studies of chromatin have demonstrated dense spherical particles called nucleosomes, which are approximately 10 nm in diameter and connected by DNA filaments. Nucleosomes are composed of DNA wound around an octameric complex of histone molecules.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 351

questions.text: All of the following are high-energy compounds, except
questions.solution:
High energy compounds are those which contain energy rich bond. They are present in all living cells, participating in the energy accumulation and conversion processes.

They include

  1. ATP (Adenosine tri phosphate) (Option A)
  2. acyl carrier protein (Option B)
  3. S-adenosylmethionine (active methionine) (Option D),
  4. thiol esters involving coenzyme A (eg, acetyl- CoA),
  5. amino acid esters involved in protein synthesis,
  6. uridine diphosphate glucose (UDPGlc),
  7. 5-phosphoribosyl- 1-pyrophosphate (PRPP).

Option C: Glucose is not considered as high energy compounds as it does not contain energy rich bonds. Glucose can produce energy by its breakdown. One molecule of glucose (6C, aldo hexose) when complete breakdown into 6 CO2 (by glycolysis, TCA cycle & electron transport chain), it will produce net 32 ATPs.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 108

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme protects aerobic organism against oxygen toxicity?
questions.solution:
Option A: Superoxide dismutase protects aerobic organisms against oxygen toxicity

Transfer of a single electron to O2 generates the potentially damaging superoxide anion free radical (O2-) which gives rise to free-radical chain reactions and amplifying its destructive effects. Such superoxide can be formed from oxygen in tissues easily. So the presence of superoxide dismutase (SOD) enzyme is responsible for its removal in all aerobic organisms (although not in obligate anaerobes) and prevent the potential toxicity of oxygen is due to its conversion to superoxide.

Superoxide is formed when reduced flavins present (for example, in xanthine oxidase reaction) and it is reoxidized univalently by molecular oxygen:

Enz - Flavin - H2 + O2 -> Enz - Flavin - H + O2- + H+

Superoxide can reduce oxidized cytochrome c, which catalyzes the conversion of to oxygen and hydrogen peroxide.

O2- + Cyt c (Fe+3) -> O2 + Cyt c (Fe+2)

In this reaction, superoxide acts as both oxidant and reductant. Thus, superoxide dismutase protects aerobic organisms against the potential deleterious effects of super­oxide. The enzyme occurs in all major aerobic tissues in the mitochondria and the cytosol. An exposure of ani­mals to an atmosphere of 100% oxygen causes prolonged exposure leads to lung damage by superoxide and can lead to death. It will also increase in SOD as an adaptive response particularly in the lungs. Other antioxidants, for example, α-tocopherol (vitamin E), act as scavengers of free radicals and reduce the toxicity of oxygen.

Option B: Monooxygenase is a Mixed-Function Oxidases. It Incorporate Only One Atom of Molecular Oxygen into the Substrate.

Option C: Dioxygenase incorporate Both Atoms of Molecular Oxygen into the Substrate

Option D: Cytochrome oxidase is complex 4 of electron transport chain.

Monooxygenase, Dioxygenase, Cytochrome oxidase takes part in electron transport chain. They have no role in neutralizing free radicals like superoxide.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 116

questions.text: Following diagram depicts overview of electron flow through various complexes of electron transport chain. Name the missing complex in following diagram (marked with question mark).
questions.solution:
Electron flow through four complexes in electron transport chain.

Complex I: NADH Coenzyme Q oxidoreductase (Option C)

It not NAD or oxidase (Option A, B, D)

Complex II: Succinate Coenzyme Q reductase

Complex III: Coenzyme Q cytochrome c oxidoreductase

Complex IV: Cytochrome c oxidase



Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 119

questions.text: Barbiturates at very high dosage is fatal, because it inhibits electron transport chain via:
questions.solution:
Inhibitors of respiratory chain provided knowledge about the mechanism of action of several poisons & drugs which are fatal at high dose.

Option A: Barbiturates such as amobarbital inhibit electron transport via Complex I by blocking the transfer from Fe-S to Q. At sufficient high dosage, they are fatal.

Option B: Malonate is a competitive inhibitor of Complex II.

Option C: Antimycin A and dimercaprol inhibit the respiratory chain at Complex III.

Option D: H2S, carbon monoxide, and cyanide inhibit Complex IV and can therefore totally arrest respiration.



Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 132

questions.text: Which of the following protein act as uncoupling protein, which uncouple oxidation from phosphorylation?
questions.solution:
Option A: Albumin is a plasma protein, not act as uncoupler

Option B: Glycogenin is a protein found in core of glycogen, not a uncoupler

Option C: Thermogenin is protein found in brown adipose tissue, act as physiological uncoupler which uncouple oxidation from phosphorylation

Option D: Carnitine is fatty acid transport protein found in mitochondrial membrane, help to transport activated fatty acid from cytoplasm to mitochondria during beta oxidation of fatty acids. It will not act as uncoupler protein.

Uncouplers dissociate oxidation in the respiratory chain from phosphorylation. These compounds are toxic, causing respiration to become uncontrolled, since the rate is no longer limited by the concentration of ADP or Pi.



Chemical Uncouplers:

The uncoupler that has been used most frequently is 2,4- dinitrophenol. Other chemical uncouplers are dicumarol (anticoagulant), CCCP (chlorocarbonylcyanide phenylhydrazone), salicylate (metabolite of aspirin)

Physiological Uncouplers:

Thermogenin (or the uncoupling protein) is a physiologic uncoupler found in brown adipose tissue that functions to generate body heat, particularly for the newborn and during hibernation in animals.

Some other physiological uncoupler are thyroxine, bilirubin and free fatty acids. But these compounds normally not present in concentration high enough to act as uncouplers.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 132

questions.text: Substrate level phosphorylation in kerb's cycle is seen at step catalyzed by:
questions.solution:
One ATP is generated directly in TCA cycle at the succinate thiokinase step, an examples of substrate level phosphorylation

Option A: Alpha keto glutarate dehydrogenase is an enzyme in kreb’s cycle which convert alpha keto glutarate into succinyl CoA. But ATP is not generated in this reaction.

Option B: Pyruvate Kinase is an enzyme in glycolysis which convert phosphoenol pyruvate into in to pyruvate. It generates one ATP, an example of substrate level phosphorylation, but in glycolysis not in kreb’s cycle.

Option C: Succinate thiokinase is an enzyme in kreb’s cycle which convert succinyl CoA into succinate, and generate GTP which convert into ATP. It is also an example of substrate level phosphorylation in kreb’s cycle.

Option D: Creatine Kinase is an enzyme involve in muscle energy metabolism. It convert creatine phosphate into creatine and produce ATP. It is also an example of substrate level phosphorylation in muscle, not in kreb’s cycle.



Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 152

questions.text: Which one of the following is provitamin A?
questions.solution:
Retinoids comprise retinol, retinaldehyde, and retinoic acid (preformed vitamin A, found only in foods of animal origin); carotenoids, found in plants, are a variety of carotenes and related compounds; many are precursors of vitamin A, as they can be cleaved to yield retinaldehyde, then retinol and retinoic acid.

The α-, β-, and γ-carotenes and crypto­xanthin are quantitatively the most important provitamin A carotenoids.

Option A: Retinol is vitamin A alcohol

Option B: Retinal is vitamin A aldehyde

Option C: Retinoic acid is vitamin A acid

Option D: crypto­xanthin, α-, β-, and γ-carotenes are provitamin A carotenoids

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 529

questions.text: Deficiency of vitamin A impairs vitamin D and thyroid hormone function because of lack of 9-cis-retinoic acid to form active receptor dimers with which one of the following receptor?
questions.solution:
There are two families of nuclear retinoid receptors: the retinoic acid receptors (RAR) bind all-trans-retinoic acid or 9-cis-retinoic acid, and the retinoid X receptors (RXR) bind 9-cis-retinoic acid.

RXRs also form dimers with vitamin D, thyroid, and other nuclear acting hormone receptors. Defi­ciency of vitamin A impairs vitamin D and thyroid hor­mone function because of lack of 9-cis-retinoic acid to form active receptor dimers. Unoccupied RXRs form dimers with occupied vitamin D and thyroid hormone receptors, but not only do these not activate gene expression, they may repress it, so that vitamin A deficiency has a more severe effect on vitamin D and thyroid hormone function than simply failure to activate gene expression. Excessive vitamin A also impairs vitamin D and thyroid hormone function, because of forma­tion of RXR homodimers, meaning that there are not enough RXR available to form heterodimers with the vitamin D and thyroid hormone receptors.

Option A: retinoic acid receptors (RAR) bind all-trans-retinoic acid or 9-cis-retinoic acid

Option B: retinoid X receptors (RXR) bind 9-cis-retinoic acid.

RXRs also form dimers with vitamin D, thyroid, and other nuclear acting hormone receptors. Defi­ciency of vitamin A impairs vitamin D and thyroid hor­mone function because of lack of 9-cis-retinoic acid to form active receptor dimers.

Option C: Retinoic acid, vitamin D, thyroid have nuclear acting hormone receptors, not cytoplasmic receptor

Option D: Vitamin D receptor is for only calcitriol

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 529

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequences of organ involved in vitamin D metabolism?
questions.solution:
Vitamin D Is Synthesized in the Skin then metabolized to the Active Metabolite, Calcitriol, in Liver & Kidney. Then calcitriol finally act on target organ like bone.

7-Dehydrocholesterol (an intermediate in the synthesis of cholesterol that accumulates in the skin) undergoes a nonenzymic reaction on exposure to ultraviolet light, yield­ing previtamin D. This undergoes a further reaction over a period of hours to form cholecalciferol, which is absorbed into the bloodstream.

Cholecalciferol, either synthesized in the skin or from food, undergoes two hydroxylations to yield the active metabolite, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D or calcitriol. Ergocal­ciferol from fortified foods undergoes similar hydroxylation to yield ercalcitriol.

In the liver, cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to form the 25-hydroxy derivative, calcidiol. This is released into the circulation bound to a vitamin D–binding globulin, which is the main storage form of the vitamin.

In the kidney, calcidiol undergoes either 1-hydroxylation to yield the active metabolite 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol), or 24-hydroxylation to yield a probably inactive metabolite, 24,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (24-hydroxycalcidiol).



So the correct sequences of organ involved in vitamin D metabolism is Skin -> Liver -> Kidney à Bone (Option A).

Rest other sequences given in option B, C, D is incorrect.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 530

questions.text: Most active form of vitamin E is:
questions.solution:
Vitamin E is the generic descriptor for two families of compounds, the tocopherols and the tocotrienols. The different vitamers have different biologic potency.



Option A: L-α-tocopherol is inactive

Option B: D-α-tocopherol is most active

Option C: Synthetic DL-α-tocopherol does not have the same biologic potency as the naturally occurring compound.

Option D: tocopherols have more biological potency than tocotrienols

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 532

questions.text: All of the following compounds have biological activity of vitamin K except
questions.solution:
Three compounds have the biological activity of vitamin K.

Phylloquinone, the normal dietary source, found in green vegetables (Option A)

Menaquinones, synthesized by intestinal bacteria, with differing lengths of side chain (Option C)

Menadione and menadiol diacetate, synthetic compounds that can be metabolized to phylloquinone (Option D)

Tocopherol have vitamin E activity (Option B)

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 532

questions.text: Thiamine Nutritional Status Can Be Assessed by addition of thiamine diphosphate in vitro in erythrocyte lysate to assess activity of which of the following enzyme?
questions.solution:
Option A: Thiamine diphosphate is also the coenzyme for transketolase, in the pentose phosphate pathway.

The activation of apotransketolase (the enzyme protein) in erythrocyte lysate by thiamine diphosphate added in vitro has become the accepted index of thiamine nutritional status.

Option B: Glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase is an enzyme involved in HMP shunt, but it doesn’t require thiamine diphosphate as coenzyme.

Option C & D: Pyruvate kinase & Hexokinase are enzyme involved in glycolysis in RBC, but it doesn’t require thiamine diphosphate as coenzyme.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 534

questions.text: All of following vitamin deficiency can lead to pellagra, except:
questions.solution:
Pellagra is characterized by a photosensitive dermatitis. As the condition progresses, there is depressive psychosis and possibly diarrhea. Untreated pellagra is fatal.

Option A: Niacin deficiency can lead to pellagra.

Option B & C: Riboflavin & vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) both of which are required for synthesis of nicotinamide from tryptophan, so deficiency of these two vitamin can also lead to pellagra

Option D: Folic acid has no role in niacin metabolism directly or indirectly, so folic acid deficiency cannot lead to pellagra.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 535

questions.text: Biotin is act as coenzyme for enzyme
questions.solution:
Option A: Biotin Is a Coenzyme of Carboxylase Enzymes

Option B: Coenzyme for oxidoreductase enzyme are NAD, NADP, FAD or FMN (niacin or riboflavin)

Option C: Pyridoxal phosphate is coenzyme for transaminase enzymes

Option D: Thiamine is coenzyme for transketolase enzyme.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 539

questions.text: All of the following are inhibitor of enzyme dihydro folate reductase, except:
questions.solution:
The one-carbon fragment of methylene-tetrahydrofolate is reduced to a methyl group with release of dihydrofolate, which is then reduced back to tetrahydrofolate by dihydrofolate reductase. Thy­midylate synthase and dihydrofolate reductase are especially active in tissues with a high rate of cell division.

Option A: Methotrexate, an analogue of 10-methyltetrahydrofolate, inhibits dihydrofolate reductase and is used as in cancer chemotherapy.

Option B and Option D: The dihy­drofolate reductases of some bacteria and parasites differ from the human enzyme; inhibitors of these enzymes can be used as antibacterial drugs (eg, trimethoprim) and antimalarial drugs (eg, pyrimethamine).

Option C: Sulphonamides is an antibacterial agents

Bacterial cell synthesize folic acid in cell by combining Para amino benzoic acid (PABA) with pteroyl glutamic acid (PGA) by Folate synthase enzymes. This folic acid is required for bacterial multiplication. Sulphonamides drugs is structural analogues of PABA, so it will inhibit folate synthase enzyme, so inhibit folic acid synthesis in bacteria, and so bacterial cell division is stop and they die.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition PN 537
